comments.body: https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/pull/2200 implements the function style, [this commit](https://github.com/styled-components/styled-components/commit/ba34abe681f4962a5ee160421bb80eede0d196a3) deprecates the object-with-functions style
Thanks for jumping on this so quickly!
Good news is, these two overloads are sufficient to implement the `as` prop in TS 3.2. The bad news is, their presence at all causes everything to break in TS<3.2.
This problem not even TS 3.2 solves...

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +126,130 @@             * Typing Note: prefer using .withComponent for now as it is actually type-safe.
             *
             * String types need to be cast to themselves to become literal types (as={'a' as 'a'}).
             */
            as?: keyof JSX.IntrinsicElements | React.ComponentType<any>

comments.body: Oops, I forgot to add CSSObject support here.

One potential breaking change I noticed in my own code is that `U`'s inference seems to be more eager.

If you have two function interpolations, and only the second one annotates its props, `U` is still inferred as `{}` instead of as the annotated type of the second interpolation. The first interpolation is the one that needs its props.

I don't know if `keyframes` accepts the `InterpolationFunction` variation. It does have `SimpleInterpolation[]` in the second overload.

(actually, I haven't tested this either; more homework...)

The `StyleSheet` in the source code is not the DOM `StyleSheet` which this was accidentally referring to but a private class that is not exported so I didn't define it here.

At any rate, the `instance` at runtime will be a `ServerStyleSheet` instance anyway so I just made it be `this` typed.

They can be arbitrarily nested.

```
> sc.css([[[[[[['color: green;']]]]]]])
[ 'color: green;' ]
```

Same with `SimpleInterpolation`

```
> sc.keyframes([[[[[[['from { color: green; }']]], { to: { color: 'red' } }]]]])
Keyframes {
  inject: [Function],
  toString: [Function],
  name: 'ijNbFt',
  rules:
   [ '@-webkit-keyframes ijNbFt{from{color:green;}to{color:red;}}',
     '@keyframes ijNbFt{from{color:green;}to{color:red;}}' ],
  id: 'sc-keyframes-ijNbFt' }
```

However, keyframes absolutely cannot take any function. It'll just call `.toString()` on it and add to the rules.
This wasn't excluding any `theme` that might have been expected by interpolations, so it'd be kept as a required prop.

This kinda doesn't belong here as it can't be affected by the type of theme anyway...... but on the other hand, omitting it would make it harder to use, with you having to import `keyframes` from elsewhere instead of from your strongly typed wrapper.

I couldn't find any way to test this in an isolated context that wouldn't affect the type of `DefaultTheme` as seen from `index.tsx`. It's very important for the existing tests that `DefaultTheme` be empty...

However, augmenting `DefaultTheme` did cause expected type errors so it seems to work ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

Interesting trick üëÄ

I wonder if this can be used to work around some issues I encountered with union types... e.g. `react-redux`'s `connect` always collapses unions.
Does this work with `Memo` / `Lazy`? I remember I had to add specific support for them in `LibraryManagedAttributes`
Hm... I didn't try. It may worth trying this. I suspect that it will work since `ReactDefaultizedProps` is simplified version of `LibraryManagedAttributes`.
